source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_036_chunk1
evidence_span: A modest crud buildup of $\sim 5$ to 6 mils was evident in some of the flow holes in the tube sheet

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_036_chunk1
evidence_span: The maximum crud thickness (8 mils) was found at the inlet end of Rod 10, Bundle 070

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_036_chunk1
evidence_span: The thinnest crud deposits $( \sim 1 \mathrm { \ m i l } )$ were usually observed in the central portions of each rod

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_036_chunk2
evidence_span: The bulk of the oxide corrosion film was found to be uniform gray-tan in color, typical of a Zircaloy post-transition corrosion product.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_036_chunk2
evidence_span: The ends of the rods immediately adjacent to the end caps (tube sheets) were found to exhibit a mottled appearance with small local regions of gray-tan oxide over black corrosion film.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_036_chunk2
evidence_span: This visual observation was interpreted to mean that there was less corrosion product buildup (black oxide) in the end cap regions than on the rest of the rod (gray oxide).

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_036_chunk2
evidence_span: Subsequent destructive measurements of the oxide film thicknesses of each road substantiated the significant difference in corrosion attack between the end cap regions and the remainder of the rod.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_036_chunk2
evidence_span: The total 154 time increments accounted for a total of 4120 days at temperature.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_036_chunk2
evidence_span: employing a value of 1.0 Btu/h-ft- ℉ for the thermal conductivity of the oxide

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_036_chunk2
evidence_span: Twenty random oxide film thickness measurements were obtained from each metallographic sample; the average value, range, and standard deviation of the data from each cladding region are shown in Table 1.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_036_chunk2
evidence_span: The hydrogen chemical analysis values, obtained by hot vacuum extraction, are also recorded in Table 1 for each cladding region.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_036_chunk2
evidence_span: Finally, a single "effective" corrosion temperature over the lifetime of the component was calculated from the predicted oxide film thickness and total exposure time (4120 days)

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_036_chunk5
evidence_span: At the end of four seed lives in Core 1, blanket rods were found to contain oxide film thicknesses $\sim 0 . 4 \mu \mathrm { m }$ (0.016 mils) greater than predicted values

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_036_chunk5
evidence_span: a minimum difference of $3 . 3 \mu \mathrm { m }$ (0.13 mils) and an average difference between predicted and measured values of $5 . 4 \ \mu \mathrm { m }$ (0.21 mils)

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_036_chunk5
evidence_span: the current set of MELBA data produce acceleration factors of 1.7 to 3.0, with an average value of 2.4

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_036_chunk5
evidence_span: Bundle 070 actually produced the thinnest oxides whereas the maximum corrosion products were found on the bundle that experienced lower temperatures but greater fast fluence accumulations (Bundle 202)

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_036_chunk5
evidence_span: Bundle 202 experienced lower temperatures but greater fast fluence accumulations

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_036_chunk5
evidence_span: the MELBA rods corroded as if they were exposed to a temperature range over life of $\sim 5 6 0$ to ${ \mathfrak { s } } { \mathfrak { s } } 0 ^ { \circ } { \mathfrak { F } }$ instead of the predicted 520 to ${ \mathfrak { s } } 4 0 ^ { \circ } { \mathfrak { F } }$ , an increase of approximately $4 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { F }$

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_036_chunk5
evidence_span: The observed corrosion acceleration was accompanied by a reduced hydrogen pickup

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_036_chunk5
evidence_span: less than half of the anticipated hydrogen uptake was actually found in the cladding

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_036_chunk5
evidence_span: Water specifications for the Shippingport PWR require only that the makeup water contain $< 0 . 1 4$ ppm oxygen

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_036_chunk6
evidence_span: The longterm out-of-reactor (autoclave) Zircaloy-2 corrosion data of Kass [7] were employed to derive an empirical relationship equating the post-transition (linear) corrosion rate constant with an exponential function of the reciprocal of the absolute temperature of the corroding surface

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_036_chunk6
evidence_span: Zircaloy corrosion acceleration would not take place in the highly reducing environment of the PWR coolant

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_036_chunk6
evidence_span: the large discrepancy between measured and predicted oxide film thicknesses in the current examination is assumed to be indicative of the excess corrosion associated with the fast neutron irradiation exposure, even in the presence of a highly reducing environment

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_036_chunk6
evidence_span: the axial distribution of oxide film thicknesses on the fuel rods is predicted by the ex-reactor empirical equation due, primarily, to the predicted surface temperature gradients derived from measured bulk coolant temperatures, crud thicknesses, and axial heat flux values

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_036_chunk6
evidence_span: The measured oxide film thicknesses at each axial location of a fuel rod appears to be an approximate constant excess quantity above the corresponding predicted values from the ex-reactor correlation

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_036_chunk6
evidence_span: the predicted and measured oxide film thickness gradients are very similar
